nodes.bodyText:
Do we need this? Because according to the doco:

Please note that this is done automatically if the testing framework you're using supports the afterEach global (like mocha, Jest, and Jasmine).

We're using Jest, so..... 🤔
What you've done in this function now matches a generic function I've provided for this test file over in #2172

This should either be in the "Refine search by Owner" describe block, or this combined with the below for date modified should be in their own describe bock, maybe something like: describe("Configuring hiding refine search controls", () => {

I've already canonicalised the method of finding this selector as you can see in the "Refine Search by Owner" block, getOwnerFilter().
If this test won't be joining the block, then we should move that function out into a helper file.
But you'll also note I've further standardised the approach with a generic function for grabbing the selectors #2172. Although they are using the IDs (so not something the user can see), I feel that makes it more robust.
And as a side note, where possible we should use the language strings, not string literals.

I'm not sure this is correct. As ownerSelector is an Element instance that belonged to a previously rendered DOM. As a result, you really should be running the getter again. Ideally ownerSelector would be a function, like my aforementioned getOwnerFilter - renamed getOwnerSelector in #2172 .
So as a result, you're getting a false positive here - and pretty well always would even if the control was there. To check that though, you could comment out your mocking of the mockSearchSettings value.
Should we make this optional, so it can kind of default to false?

hmmmm, because these are getting changed via an effect, if the default is true but then the server says false will there be a momentary rendering of them? (I think I've seen this kind of visual effect with how we show the settings - they initially render in one state, and then swap to what we get from the server.) Maybe none should be rendered until we've heard from the server to ensure smooth UX - rather than disappearing controls.
So it turns out they all currently have a default of false and as a result this should just be a case of a delay in showing the components. That should be AOK. 👍

To reduce nesting and increase readability, could we:
{controls
.filter( c => !c.disabled )
.map( (control) => (
  <ListItem ...>
    ...
  </ListItem>
)}

So this is the same as the start of getRefineComponent, so arguably getRefineComponent should have been updated to use this rather than repeating the logic.
Although you have gone with queryByAttribute rather than stay with the container.querySelector. Why was that?
